content.text: Measure the dimensions of the block of modelling clay, as shown in Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2
Calculate the volume \(V_{1}\) of the block, using your measurements from **(a)(i)** and the equation \(V_{1} = l \times w \times h\)
Suggest a possible source of inaccuracy in measuring the dimensions of the block and describe an improvement to the procedure that will produce more reliable measurements of the block
suggestion
improvement
The student suspends the piece of modelling clay from a forcemeter, as shown in Fig. 1.3
Record the weight \(W\) of the block of modelling clay shown in Fig. 1.3
Calculate a value \(\rho_{1}\) for the density of the modelling clay, using your results from **(a)(ii)** and **(c)** and the equation
where \(k = 100g / N.\)
Record the volume \(V_{2}\) of the water in the measuring cylinder shown in Fig. 1.4
Describe how a measuring cylinder is read to obtain an accurate value for the volume of water. You may draw a diagram to help you
The student pours some water into a measuring cylinder, as shown in Fig. 1.4
• Record the new reading \(V_{3}\) of the measuring cylinder in Fig. 1.5, with the block of modelling clay in the water
• Calculate another value \(\rho_{2}\) for the density of modelling clay, using your value for \(V_{3}\), your readings from (c) and (e)(i) and the equation
where \(k = 100g / N.\)
Suggest which of \(\rho_{1}\) or \(\rho_{2}\) is likely to be the more accurate value for the density of the modelling clay
Justify your answer by referring to the procedure
The student lowers the modelling clay into the water, as shown in Fig. 1.5
A student is determining the density of modelling clay
He is using the block shown in Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2
Fig. 1.2 (side view)
The crocodile clip is connected to a length of the resistance wire. The current in the circuit and potential difference (p.d.) across wire \(\mathbf{X}\) are measured
On Fig. 2.1, draw the symbol for a voltmeter correctly connected to measure the p.d. across wire \(\mathbf{X}\). [1]
A student adjusts the position of the crocodile clip until the current in the circuit is 0.80A
In Table 2.1, record the value of the p.d. \(V\) across wire \(\mathbf{X}\), as shown in Fig. 2.2
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (y-axis) against \(I / A\) (x-axis)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
Fig. 2.3 shows wire \(\mathbf{X}\)
• On Fig. 2.3, measure the length \(l\)
• The wire in Fig. 2.3 is shown to \(1 / 3^{\text{rd}}\) scale. Calculate the actual length \(L\) of wire \(\mathbf{X}\)
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of each centimetre of wire \(\mathbf{X}\), using the equation
where \(k = 1.0 \Omega \text{cm}\)
Give the value for \(R\), to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
The student records the p.d. \(V\) for different currents, as shown in Table 2.1
A student notices that the resistance wire becomes very hot when the crocodile clip is connected to short lengths of the wire
Suggest an improvement that would help to reduce this effect
[Total: 11]
Some students are determining the resistance per unit length of wire \(\mathbf{X}\)
They are using the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1
Measure and record in Table 3.1 the angle \(\alpha\) between \(\mathbf{AN}\) and \(\mathbf{CN}\) , as shown in Fig. 3.1
Draw a normal to \(\mathbf{AB}\) at point \(\mathbf{N}\) , towards the top of the page. Label the top point of this normal \(\mathbf{L}\)

Two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) are placed on line \(\mathbf{LN}\) , a suitable distance apart for ray tracing. On Fig. 3.1, label suitable positions for \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\)
Draw a line passing through \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and reaching point \(\mathbf{N}\)
Measure the angle \(\theta\) between this line and the normal \(\mathbf{LN}\)
Record this value in Table 3.1
The student places the reflecting surface of a plane mirror on line \(\mathbf{CD}\) and views the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1

She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), and the pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), all appear exactly one behind the other
Draw a line passing through \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\) and reaching point \(\mathbf{N}\)
Measure the angle \(\theta\) between this new line and the normal \(\mathbf{LN}\)
Record this value in Table 3.1
The student moves the mirror to a line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at an angle \(\alpha = 35^{\circ}\) to \(\mathbf{AN}\). Line \(\mathbf{EF}\) is not shown in Fig. 3.1
The student repeats the process with the mirror on \(\mathbf{EF}\) and places pins \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\) in line with the new images
A student suggests that when the mirror is moved, the change in \(\theta\) should be equal to twice the change in \(\alpha\)
State whether your readings support this idea. Justify your answer with reference to the readings
statement
justification
Suggest two precautions that you would take to ensure accurate results from this type of experiment
A student is investigating the reflection of light by a plane mirror
Her ray-trace sheet is shown in Fig. 3.1
A student is investigating the conduction of thermal energy by metals
Plan an experiment to compare the rates at which different metals conduct thermal energy
The apparatus available includes:
strips of different metals, shaped as shown in Fig. 4.1
a test-tube in a clamp stand
a beaker
a supply of cold water
a supply of hot water
The shorter section of each strip of metal can fit inside a test-tube
Write a plan for the experiment
You should:
• list any additional apparatus needed
• draw a labelled diagram of how the apparatus will be arranged
• explain briefly how you will carry out the experiment
• explain how the metals will be compared
• state the precautions which should be taken to obtain reliable results
